facts.text: Appellant Bhagwan Singh convicted of murder of Buggar Singh and sentenced to death; also convicted under section 19 of Indian Arms Act.

Appellant bore grudge against deceased because deceased fired at appellant's brother six or seven years before occurrence and was sent to jail; police took proceedings under section 107 CrPC binding down appellant's two brothers, cousins, and deceased.
Motive proved by Bhag Singh PW7, believed by courts.
On 7th September 1950, about 12:15 p.m., appellant sitting at shop of Jit Singh PW2; deceased came, borrowed Rs.5 from Jit Singh, entered in account book, left shop.
Appellant followed deceased and shot him at point blank range with pistol, 4 or 5 karams from shop.
Bystanders chased appellant, apprehended after short run of 30 karams; still carrying pistol, taken by Jagir Singh Patwari PW4.
Appellant taken to local police post 100 karams away; Jit Singh PW2 made first information report at 12:27 p.m., within 15 minutes of occurrence.
Occurrence witnessed by large number of persons; prosecution examined five; two turned hostile in Sessions Court, one neutral; Balbir Singh PW5 and Jaswant Singh PW6 believed by High Court.
Jaswant Singh PW6 not examined by Committing Magistrate as he was unavailable and had gone away.

Jit Singh PW2 supported prosecution in examination-in-chief but resiled in cross-examination, treated hostile, cross-examined by prosecutor; his Committal Court statement read out, admitted making it, tallied with chief and FIR.
Jagir Singh PW4 hostile from start; cross-examined point by point on Committal statement, admitted making it.
Jit Singh PW2 and Jagir Singh PW4 stated their Committal statements not read over to them and made under police threats/duress.
Committing Magistrate's certificate states depositions read over and admitted correct.
Appellant represented by two counsel in Sessions Court.
Jaswant Singh mentioned as eyewitness in FIR and committal calendar; appellant had access to police statements under s.162 CrPC.

legal_issues.text: Whether the conviction can be rested on the testimony of Balbir Singh PW5 and Jaswant Singh PW6.
Whether Jaswant Singh PW6 not being examined by Committing Magistrate makes his Sessions evidence inadmissible.
Whether irregularities in trial, including examination under s.540 CrPC by prosecutor instead of court, vitiate the trial.
Whether High Court used prior statements of Jit Singh PW2 and Jagir Singh PW4 as substantive evidence without s.288 CrPC formalities or s.145 Evidence Act compliance.
Whether Committal statements not read over (per witness testimony) renders them inadmissible.
Whether statements made under police duress without enquiry vitiates.
Whether substantial compliance with s.342 CrPC.

petitioner_arguments.text: Evidence of Jaswant Singh PW6 inadmissible as not examined by Committing Magistrate; s.208 CrPC violated; s.540 not applicable or improperly used.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: CrPC ss.208, 540; Sher Bahadur v. Crown

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court used Committal statements of Jit Singh PW2 and Jagir Singh PW4 as substantive evidence despite no s.288 CrPC; s.145 Evidence Act not complied.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: CrPC s.288; Evidence Act s.145; Tara Singh v. State

petitioner_arguments.text: Committal statements not read over to witnesses; certificate presumed false without enquiry.
Statements made under police threats/duress; requires enquiry.
No proper compliance with s.342 CrPC; prejudice caused.

respondent_arguments.text: Eyewitnesses Balbir and Jaswant reliable; appellant apprehended on spot with pistol; FIR prompt.

court_reasoning.text: Jaswant PW6 not examined in committal due to unavailability; s.540 CrPC allows examination in Sessions; examined by prosecutor is irregularity curable by s.537; no objection at trial; no prejudice as mentioned in FIR and calendar.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No prejudice; too late to object.

court_reasoning.text: High Court primarily relied on Balbir and Jaswant; comments on Jit and Jagir not necessary for conviction.
Jit PW2: hostile in cross; admitted Committal statement; used for corroboration under Evidence Act s.157, not contradiction needing s.145; s.288 makes substantive if needed.
Jagir PW4: s.145 complied substantially; questioned point by point, admitted statement.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fair opportunity given; substance over form.

court_reasoning.text: Presume certificate under Evidence Act s.80 correct; burden on appellant to disprove; no duty to enquire.
Even if not read over, curable irregularity absent prejudice shown by affidavit.
Allegations of duress collateral; burden on appellant not discharged.
Substantial compliance with s.342; simple facts; no prejudice shown.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No specific prejudice or answers disclosed.

court_reasoning.text: Simple case: caught red-handed with pistol, prompt FIR.

holdings.text: Testimony of PW5 and PW6 sufficient for conviction; no prejudice from irregularities.
Witness not examined in committal can be examined in Sessions under s.540 CrPC; prosecutor examination curable irregularity absent prejudice.
Prior statements can corroborate chief evidence under Evidence s.157; s.288 CrPC transmutes to substantive; s.145 not always needed if admitted.
s.80 Evidence Act presumes magistrate certificate correct absent proof otherwise; no enquiry duty.
Substantial compliance with s.342 CrPC where no prejudice.

precedents_cited.relevance: Omission curable; decided on prejudice, conceded s.540 power.
Sessions refusal to examine not applicable.
Against appellant's contention on committal witnesses.
Full Bench against contention on committal witnesses.
Magistrate refused examination and prevented cross; not applicable.
No choice of versions; hostile from start for contradiction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kashmira Singh v. The State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Undesirability of examining magistrate on certificate.
Undesirability of examining magistrate on certificate.
Not reading over curable absent prejudice by affidavit.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Bindings, statements, committal, examination of witnesses, irregularities, explanation to accused.

outcome.summary: Appeal against conviction and death sentence for murder dismissed; all technical objections rejected for lack of prejudice; conviction rests on eyewitnesses and circumstances of apprehension on spot with weapon.

key_quotes.text: This is a simple case though it was argued at great length on behalf of the appellant and a number of technical objections to the validity of the trial taken.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Summarizes nature of case and dismisses technicalities.

key_quotes.text: The case is a very simple one in which a man was caught red-handed with a pistol still in his hand and in which the first information report was recorded practically on the spot within 15 minutes of the occurrence.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Crux of why conviction upheld despite technical arguments.

key_quotes.text: The irregularity here on this score, if indeed it is one, is so trivial as to be innocuous.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: On examination by prosecutor under s.540.

key_quotes.text: The matter is one of substance and not of mere form.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: On s.145 compliance for Jagir Singh.
